title: Energy efficient appliances, light bulbs: Are they worth it? | Life Lifestyle | Lifestyle and Living | |
text:
But the true amount of those savings has been called into question after a recent US study found that the money saved on energy bills in the long term was less than half of the initial upgrade costs.
Energy and environmental economist David Stern says he is not surprised at the results, as engineers usually over-estimate these savings when doing their calculations. “If it was really a great way to save money, more people would do it themselves and wouldn’t need a government program to get them to do it,” he explains. “The upfront costs though would probably put it out of the reach of lots of low-income households, even if it did pay off in the long run.”
We all think more stars are better, but the energy savings may never cover the cost. Source: News Limited
While the study was conducted in the northern US state of Michigan, David explains that Australia’s more temperate climate and higher electricity prices mean that there are probably even much lower gains possible in terms of saved energy. “Especially in cities like Melbourne, Sydney or Adelaide and Perth. Most of these don’t have a huge need for airconditioning on an annual basis either,” he says.
However, Martin Kushler of the American Council for an Energy Efficient America argued that the study was too narrow and the results have been blown out of proportion. In a blog post analysing the study , he claimed that several national studies have previously examined other residential energy efficiency programs across many US states and have found them to be highly cost effective.
Energy Efficiency Council chief executive officer Luke Menzel said Australian households used a lot more energy than they needed to, but the good news was that Australian families could make big gains by taking straightforward actions.
“Research has shown that some of the cheapest ways that households can save energy is by putting in more efficient light bulbs and cutting down on the number of appliances they leave in standby mode,” he says. “After you do these simple things, it can be really worth upgrading old appliances that tend to be big energy hogs, like hot water systems and pool pumps.”
David says that while it makes sense to use more energy efficient equipment and building methods to a certain degree on new homes, and replace worn out equipment with more energy efficient equipment, it will make less sense to replace stuff that still has reasonable life in it. He recommends checking the energy star ratings of different appliances, and doing your research on homes, where possible. “You can get information on the energy savings of different rated houses, but it seems to need a bit of web search to uncover it,” he says.
An Ausbuild eight-star energy efficient home. Source: Supplied
And Luke still argues that for those able to afford the extra outlay, the energy star rating can pay off in the long run. “It’s often worth spending a bit more money upfront, so you don’t end up paying through the nose on your energy bill for the next 10 or 15 years,” he says.
ClimateWorks Australia provides fact sheets on various household savings for some states, based on findings from the Low Carbon Lifestyle series.
Examples given for a large house include:
● Upgrading to energy efficient light bulbs can save about $130 a year and cut emissions from energy use by 4 per cent in Victoria
● Switching to energy-efficient showerheads can save about $230 a year in NSW, $160 a year in Queensland and $315 a year in South Australia
● Upgrading to an energy-efficient pool pump will save about $390 a year in Victoria, $380 in NSW, $260 in Queensland and $500 in South Australia. Upgrading to an efficient hot water system can save about $930 a year in South Australia and $650 in NSW
● Switching to solar panels can deliver significant savings and substantial cuts in emissions. Installing a two-kilowatt system could save about $330 a year in Victoria and $470 a year in NSW and reduce emissions from energy use by about 23 per cent
For checking specific appliances or products, the Government has released an app that helps you work out how much money you’ll save by investing in an appliance with a higher star rating.
So maybe those stars are worth it. Source: Supplied
Originally published as Are energy efficient products a rip-off?
